Situation1: Laundry piles up, but someone eventually finds time to fold it.
Expectation2: Review and analyze case files thoroughly before hearings.
Situation2: A file for a straightforward procedural hearing scheduled in two weeks has just been delivered to your chambers for preliminary review.
Story:
I stare at the mountain of laundry on the couch, shirts and socks tumbling over each other in a silent accusation. My husband’s voice echoes from the kitchen, “Could you fold those tonight? I’ve got an early meeting.” I nod, feeling the weight of expectation settle on my shoulders. I know he’s been busy, and we promised to share the chores, but my mind is already elsewhere.

On my desk, a thick manila folder sits unopened. The case is routine, a procedural hearing in two weeks, but I pride myself on being thorough. The court expects me to be prepared, to catch every detail, no matter how minor. I glance at the clock, calculating how long it would take to review the file, how long to fold the laundry, how long before exhaustion overtakes me.

My hands hover between the laundry and the file, heart pounding with the familiar tug-of-war. I want to be a good partner, to keep our home running smoothly. I want to be a diligent judge, to honor the trust placed in me. The demands pull me in opposite directions, and I can’t help but wonder which part of me will have to wait.
